Programming &klegalnotice;
This section contains some basic information for those wishing to use Kubuntu for developmental purposes.

sect1.title: Learning how to program
sect1.para: Kubuntu provides a number of resources intended to help you learn how to develop and run programs yourself. Below is a list of some resources which you may find useful.

sect2.para: Dive Into Python is a book for learning how to program in Python, aimed at programmers with some previous experience. To read the online book please review .

sect2.title: PyQt Reference
sect2.para: PyQt Reference is a guide for PyQt 4.1.1 which is a set of Python bindings for version 4 of the Qt application framework used for KDE development. To view the reference guide please review .

sect2.title: PyGTK Tutorial
sect2.para: PyGTK Tutorial is a tutorial on developing with the graphical toolkit often used for developing Ubuntu applications. It assumes that you have knowledge of Python but not necessarily GTK.

step.para: Install the python-gtk2-tutorial package (see Add Applications).
To access the documentation, visit python-gtk- tutorial.

sect2.title: Devhelp
sect2.para: Devhelp is an application to read and search all of the documentation that you install.

step.para: Install the devhelp package (see Add Applications).
Choose &menudevhelp;.

sect1.title: C and C++
sect1.para: Compiling C and C++ programs requires some packages that are not installed by default.

step.para: Install the build-essential package (see Add Applications).

sect1.para: There are many tools available for C and C++ developers. Those wishing to develop graphical applications will find that choosing a graphical toolkit/platform will make development more convenient. The two most popular development platforms for Ubuntu are GTK/GNOME and Qt/KDE, each of which has its own set of tools and documentation.

sect2.title: KDevelop IDE for KDE
sect2.para: KDevelop is an IDE for developing applications in C and C++ for the KDE platform.

step.para: Install the kdevelop package (see Add Applications).
Press &menukdevelop;

sect2.title: Qt4 Designer for KDE
sect2.para: Qt4 Designer is a tool for designing and building graphical user interfaces (GUIs) from Qt components which is used by KDE.

step.para: Install the qt4-designer package (see Add Applications).
Press &menuqt4designer;

sect2.title: Anjuta IDE for GNOME
sect2.para: Anjuta is an IDE for developing applications in C and C++ for the GNOME platform.

step.para: Install the anjuta package (see Add Applications).
Press AltF2, type anjuta and press Run to start using Anjuta.

sect1.title: Java

note.para: These instructions are for i386 and AMD64 computers only. For PowerPC machines, see Ubuntu Help Online.

step.para: Install sun-java5-jdk (see Add Applications).
Read the Java license presented. You must accept it to continue.

To get your system to use Sun Java instead of the open-source (but less functional) GIJ that is installed by default, run: sudo update-alternatives --config java and choose the option that has j2re1.5-sun in it.

sect1.para: Java 1.6 is also available, and can be installed by following the above directions, swapping all instances of 1.5 to 1.6.

sect2.title: Eclipse IDE for Java
sect2.para: The Eclipse platform provides a complete, extensible Java development environment.

step.para: Install the eclipse package (see Add Applications).
Press &menueclipse;.

sect1.title: Other programming languages
sect1.para: There are many programming tools available in Kubuntu for many different programming languages. This section provides a short list of some of the more commonly-used languages.

sect2.title: Mono .NET development environment
sect2.para: Mono is an implementation of the .NET stack, which allows you to write cross-platform programs in a number of different languages, including C#, Java, Visual Basic .NET and JavaScript. More information about Mono is available from the Mono project homepage.

step.para: Install the monodevelop and monodoc packages (see Add Applications).
Press &menumonodev;.
Press &menumonodoc; to start the Monodoc documentation browser.

sect2.title: Gambas graphical BASIC language
sect2.para: Gambas is a Visual Basic-like development environment, which allows you to rapidly design and build graphical applications using the easy-to-learn BASIC language.

step.para: Install the gambas package (see Add Applications).
Press &menugambas; to start the Gambas IDE.

sect2.para: A set of example applications are provided with Gambas, which you can use to help you to learn the language. To view an example application, start Gambas, press Examples on the Welcome to Gambas! screen and select the example which you would like to view.

sect1.title: Development Tools
sect1.para: There are many development tools available for Ubuntu. A list of some of these is included below.

sect2.title: Integrated Development Environments (IDEs) and source-code editors

listitem.para: Anjuta is an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) for C and C++.
Bluefish is a powerful editor for experienced web designers and programmers.
Eclipse is an IDE for Java and other programming languages. It forms the basis for closed-source programs such as JBuilder.
Eric is a fully featured Python and Ruby IDE.
IDLE is the Python IDE built with the Tkinter GUI toolkit.
KDevelop is a IDE for KDE which supports many programming languages.
MonoDevelop is an IDE for writing Mono/.NET applications in C# and other languages.
NetBeans is a Java IDE that features support for CVS and a form builder.
Quanta is a powerful IDE for web development and features support for DocBook editing.
Bazaar-NG is a decentralised version control system used for Ubuntu development.
CVS is an advanced version control system used by many open-source projects.
Subversion (SVN) is a powerful version control system intended as a replacement for CVS.
Glade is a user interface designer for building GNOME and GTK applications.
